prompt_sent_to_api:
You are a senior clinical geneticist. Your task is to synthesize findings from the provided analytical tool reports into a single, ranked list of potential diagnoses.

Create a master list of all unique disease candidates from all reports. Then, rank them from most to least plausible based on the strength of the evidence (consensus across tools, high scores/ranks).

Your final output must be a numbered list. Each line should contain only the rank, disease name, and OMIM ID. Do not include any reasoning or other text.

**Example Output:**
1. DISEASE NAME 1 (OMIM:XXXXXX)
2. DISEASE NAME 2 (OMIM:YYYYYY)
3. DISEASE NAME 3 (OMIM:ZZZZZZ)

---
INPUT CONTEXT

II. Analytical Tool Reports

PubCaseFinder Report (Phenotype-based):
- congenital disorder of glycosylation, type iit (Score: 0.838)
- intellectual disability, X-linked, syndromic 33 (Score: 0.830)
- chromosome 15q24 deletion syndrome (Score: 0.819)
- autosomal dominant intellectual disability-craniofacial anomalies-cardiac defects syndrome (Score: 0.810)
- Nizon-Isidor syndrome (Score: 0.808)

Zero-Shot Diagnosis Report (Generative AI-based):
- KABUKI SYNDROME 2; KABUK2 (Rank: 1)
- CORNELIA DE LANGE SYNDROME 2; CDLS2 (Rank: 2)
- COHEN SYNDROME; COH1 (Rank: 3)
- SMITH-MAGENIS SYNDROME; SMS (Rank: 4)
- RUBINSTEIN-TAYBI SYNDROME 2; RSTS2 (Rank: 5)

GestaltMatcher Report (Facial Dysmorphology-based):
- INTELLECTUAL DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDER, X-LINKED 93; XLID93 (Score: 0.465)
- ACTB (Score: 0.462)
- WHITE-SUTTON SYNDROME; WHSUS (Score: 0.458)
- HAO-FOUNTAIN SYNDROME; HAFOUS (Score: 0.438)
- SCHAAF-YANG SYNDROME; SHFYNG (Score: 0.437)

Phenotype Similarity Search Report (Vector-based):
- NOONAN SYNDROME 11 (OMIM: 618499, Score: 0.858)
- YUAN-HAREL-LUPSKI SYNDROME (OMIM: 616652, Score: 0.857)
- BASILICATA-AKHTAR SYNDROME (OMIM: 301032, Score: 0.851)
- CHROMOSOME 2p12-p11.2 DELETION SYNDROME (OMIM: 613564, Score: 0.838)
- INTELLECTUAL DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDER, AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE 73 (OMIM: 619717, Score: 0.837)

III. Supporting Literature
Web Search Results (Literature/Case Reports):
No results.
